entry.title: A MapReduce Algorithm for Matrix-Vector Multiplication
entry.content:
Algorithm Overview

Problem Definition

Suppose:

  • Square Matrix $ \mathcal{A} $ has dimension $ I\times I $ with elements $ a(i,k) $ for $ 0\leq i<I $ and $ 0\leq k<I $.
  • Column Vector $ \mathcal{B} $ has dimension $ I\times 1 $ with elements $ b(k,0) $ for $ 0\leq k<I $.

We then find:

  • Column Vector $ \mathcal{C}=\mathcal{A}\times\mathcal{B} $ has dimension $ I\times 1 $ with elements $ c(i,0) $ defined as: $ c(i,0)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{I-1} a(i,k)*b(k,0) $.
  • We split $ \mathcal{A} $ and $ \mathcal{B} $ into blocks (sub-matrices) small enough so that a pair of blocks can be multiplied in memory on a single node in the cluster and the computation only includes one phase \textbf{MapReduce}.

Notation

Notation Description
$ I $ the dimension of square matrix or column vector
$ \mathcal{A}=(a_{i,k})\in\mathbb{R}^{I\times I} $ square matrix
$ \mathcal{B}=(b_{k,0})\in\mathbb{R}^{I\times 1} $ column vector
$ \mathcal{C}=(c_{i,0})\in\mathbb{R}^{I\times 1} $ column vector
$ IB $ the number of rows per $ \mathcal{A} $ block and $ \mathcal{C} $ block.
$ KB $ the number of columns per $ \mathcal{A} $ block.
$ NIB $ the number of $ \mathcal{A} $ row and $ \mathcal{C} $ row partitions = $ (I-1)/IB+1 $.

Example

  • Naive Method: $$ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4\ 2 & 3 & 4 & 1\ 3 & 4 & 1 & 2\ 4 & 3 & 2 & 1\\\end{bmatrix}\times \begin{bmatrix}1\\3\\2\\4\end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix}29\\23\\25\\21 \end{bmatrix} $$
  • Block Strategy: $$ \left[\begin{array}{cc|cc}1 & 2 & 3 & 4\\2 & 3 & 4 & 1\\\hline3 & 4 & 1 & 2\ 4 & 3 & 2 & 1\\\end{array}\right]\times
    \left[\begin{array}{c}1\\3\\\hline2\\4\end{array}\right]=
    \left[\begin{array}{c}7\\11\\\hline 15\\13\end{array}\right]+
    \left[\begin{array}{c}22\\12\\\hline 10\\8\end{array}\right]=
    \left[\begin{array}{c}29\\23\\\hline 25\\21\end{array}\right] $$
